--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Hi, Mitchell, Ken,
> 
> Mitchell, I wasn't suggesting taking on the DARPA
> challenge as such, as 
> Ken points out there are many facets to the problem
> each of which 
> require time, research and money. However I do think
> that if the overall 
> problem is broken down into smaller problems then
> each in turn is doable 
> - some moreso than others. You say that your model
> is a greatly 
> simplified version of a real world task, which is
> true but I think that 
> if you removed the simulation of motors and motor
> control signals from 
> your model you would have something which matches
> what I described in my 
> email as the high-level control. With a few
> modifications this could 
> then be pluged-in to a larger system (each part
> developed/evolved 
> largely indepently of the others) to form part of a
> real world solution.

I agree that I would be simulating the highest level
control task related to steering and power usage.  The
methods I use, if succesful, could theoretically be
applied to a real robot, but it would be difficult,
because a fairly accurate simulation of the entire
real situation is required in order to perform
neuroevolution.  Developing this simulation is the
difficult part.  We cannot perform neuroevolution in
the actual vehicle, but only in a computer simulation.

=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
